advisors.summary: Focus first on developing the core features that deliver the essential value of the product to users, ensuring functionality and usability. Non-essential features and additional polish can be deferred to later iterations to adhere to lean principles.
risks: Overlooking critical user needs leading to poor user adoption
Cutting features that may differentiate the product competitively
Rushing to build MVP resulting in subpar quality or technical debt
Potential ethical issues if MVP compromises user data privacy or security
advisors.recommendation: Identify the fundamental problem your product solves and build the minimal set of features necessary to address it. Prioritize clarity, reliability, and user privacy in the MVP. Engage with potential users early to validate assumptions and ensure the MVP respects their dignity and autonomy. Avoid including features that do not directly contribute to the core value proposition to maintain focus and reduce waste.
advisors.name: Kantian

advisors.summary: Focus on building the core functionality that directly addresses the primary user need, while cutting non-essential features, advanced integrations, and extensive customization options to maintain a lean MVP.
risks: Competitive disadvantage if core is too minimal
Scalability issues if MVP gains traction
advisors.recommendation: Identify the single most critical user problem and build only the features that solve it. Defer secondary features, advanced UI/UX polish, admin tools, and non-critical third-party integrations. Use this MVP to validate demand and gather feedback before expanding scope.
advisors.name: Machiavellian

advisors.summary: Focus on building the core functionality that directly solves the primary user problem. Cut or postpone any advanced features, extensive UX/UI enhancements, and non-essential integrations.
risks: Core feature may not fully address user needs
Missing features could affect early user adoption
Scalability or technical debt if shortcuts are taken
MVP might not stand out from competitors
advisors.recommendation: Identify the smallest set of features that define your unique value proposition and allow real user feedback. Build only those, excluding extras such as social sharing, advanced analytics, or complex onboarding flows for the MVP phase. Validate quickly, then iterate based on actual usage and feedback.
advisors.name: User

monarch.decision: Build only the core features that address the primary user problem, deferring all non-essential features, polish, and integrations.
monarch.rationale: All active advisors agree on prioritizing a minimal feature set to solve the fundamental user need, enabling rapid validation and iteration. This approach balances lean principles with ethical commitments to user privacy, reliability, and clear value delivery, while minimizing waste and technical debt.
monarch.dissent_summary: The Optimizer advisor offered no actionable recommendation and was therefore omitted from the synthesis.
next_actions: Define the primary user problem and success criteria
List and prioritize essential MVP features
Remove or defer advanced UI/UX enhancements
Exclude non-critical integrations and admin tools
Design a simple, reliable core flow
Set up quick user testing for early feedback
